title-group.article-title: Supplemental Application of Configural Frequency Analysis to Free Sorting Data

abstract.p: Application supplémentaire de l'analyse de fréquence configurale pour le tri libre des données : L'intention de cet article est de démarrer une discussion à propos de cet outil simple et supplémentaire pour analyser des tris libres de données. Des caractéristiques communes des tris de données et de leur pertinence pour les analyses de fréquence configurale sont discutées, en relations avec l'analyse des données descriptive et confirmatoire. La taille d'échantillon pour le tri de cartes est re-examinée pour l'analyse descriptive. L'échantillon nécessaire dépend d'une certaine mesure du domaine spécifié. Le nombre moyen de différentes configurations rencontrées dépend du nombre de tris recueillies, le nombre d'éléments inclus dans le domaine et les caractéristiques du domaine. Un test simple et exact de signification est proposé pour tester les hypothèses de fréquences configurales de tri libre et flou de données.

This paper analyses the application of Configural Frequency Analysis (CFA) to free sorting data. It is intended to start a discussion about this simple supplementary analysis tool for free sorting data. Common features of sorting data and their relevance for CFA are discussed, in its approach to using both descriptive and confirmatory data analysis. Sample size requirements of card sorting are also revisited for descriptive analysis. The sample required to some extent depends on the specified domain. The average number of different configurations encountered depends on the number of sortings collected, the number of items included in the domain and the qualities of the domain. A simple exact significance test is proposed for hypothesis testing of configural frequencies in free fuzzy sorting data.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Configural frequency analysis (CFA; Lienert, 1971; Krauth and Lienert, 1973a, 1973b) is a well-established simple analysis technique used for detection of syndromes in psychology and medicine. The method has been described in more detail by Von Eye (2002), Von Eye, Mair and Mun (2010), Lautsch and Von Weber (1995) and Von Weber (2000). Frequencies of syndromes in a population are counted and tested for significance.

Sorting is a simple method that is used for collecting data about cognitive structures. When it is applied, the participants of a sorting study are given a set of items which is often printed on paper cards. The participants are then asked to sort the items into groups that make sense to them. In this type of study, a common variant is Free Sorting, where the participants are free to build any groups with respect to number, size or meaning. Partition Sorting means that participants are required to sort into mutually exclusive groups of items, while for Fuzzy Sorting into cover sets, each item can be a member of several groups simultaneously (Harloff and Coxon, 2005; Harloff, 2008). Groups (cover sets) of items from fuzzy sorting are therefore formally independent from each other, even if they stem from the same sorting.

CFA can be applied to free fuzzy sorting data, although this approach has not yet been used. This paper gives a short overview, and presents examples of the application of CFA to free sorting data. Presented first is an example of the application of CFA for descriptive purposes. The question of the number of sortings that are required is addressed. An empirical mathematical model is introduced. Subsequently, a new exact statistical test is proposed. An example of its application is presented, too.

sec.title: An example of descriptive configuration counting and graphics
Methods
sec.p: This section uses sorting data from the study of a consultancy Web site’s information architecture. 25 mutually exclusive content items from the Web site were sorted into groups by 97 business professionals and business students (most of the sortings are re-used from Harloff, 2008). Lacking a large fuzzy sorting data set, both partition and fuzzy sortings were combined in the study, although using fuzzy sortings is only recommended for practice in the future. Table 1 was constructed by counting configurations and ordering them with decreasing frequency. Singleton configurations and configurations that produced less than 4 participants were omitted to save space (due to the characteristics of the sorting procedure, each configuration count represents exactly one sorting, usually stemming from one certain participant).

sec.p: Figure 1 was subsequently produced to facilitate interpretation. The two-dimensional item space comes from multidimensional scaling using an item distance matrix constructed using the Dice index 1 as a distance measure of items. Each configuration from Table 1 is represented by a uniquely shaded graph. The widths of the graph lines are drawn proportionally to the frequencies of the related configurations. For clarity, only the shortest path connecting two items is drawn. Similar figures have been presented by several authors (for example Harloff, 2008), where graphs connecting all items have been constructed from a distance matrix spanned by items. From the mathematics involved, it makes no big difference if the line width chosen is proportional to a Dice index or to a configuration frequency. However, splitting the total graph into sub graphs representing the specified configurations seems to be a novel approach. This way one can see immediately if two items have ever been members of a common configuration.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: From all the common sorting data that are available to me, three prototypical features are apparent in Table 1. First, there are some very high incidences of configuration frequencies at the top of Table 1. Configuration frequencies then sharply decline towards the bottom of the table. The relationship between a configurations frequency and the frequency’s rank always looks like a hyperbolic curve shown in discrete integer steps. It is convenient to disregard configurations below some threshold frequency. This facilitates the interpretation.

Second, there are generally smaller configurations (up to three items) at the top of frequency tables that are implicitly included in more complex configurations located further down the table. Since these configurations usually stem from different sortings, they do not necessarily imply a hierarchy. They rather indicate different opinions. These complex relationships are easily understood with visual presentations, rather than from frequency tables.

The third observation is based on the fact that the full frequency table of Web site item configurations (including singletons and unique configurations) comprises just 139 different configurations. 139 configurations are a very small subset of the set of potential configurations. This will be demonstrated next. There are 25 items, each of which can take two different states in a configuration (either presence or absence). Therefore the full contingency table has 225 = 33,554,432 cells. This observation can be generalised. For all the sets of sorting data that were available to me, participants produced only a tiny fraction of all possible configurations. Therefore the participants are able to adequately represent a complex domain using a comparatively small set of representations. The observation thus provides evidence that the participants have been efficient in their classification and the reduction of information. Based on their experience, people may, for example, know about items that never occur together. Bimler and Kirkland (2001, 2003) describe a sorting procedure when collecting data that showed this kind of knowledge.

Figure 1 shows four distinct groups of items, although the elongated item group drawn to the right side almost falls into two groups since the “photograph of headquarters” + “transport connection map” configuration does not extend to either side into one of the subgroups. Similarly, the lower right item group drawn “behind” the elongated group almost falls into two pairs of items (connected by lines of width 17 and 20). The lower left item group also almost falls in two. By contrast, the top left group, the upper right subgroup and the bottom left subgroup are connected by configurations that comprise (almost) all of the respective items. Without line coding of configurations, these relationships could not be seen, which could lead to a different interpretation.

sec.title: Sample size requirements for descriptive configuration counting
General
sec.p: Several authors have claimed that sorting requires a small sample of participants as compared to other methods. Miller (1969) recommends using a sample of 20 participants. In a set of 50 illustratory examples of sorting experiments provided by Coxon (1999: Table 4), sample sizes vary from 5 to 200, with a median of 50. Tullis and Wood (2004) performed a bootstrapping 2 simulation study based on a sample of 168 participants. They recommend a sample size of 20 to 30 participants, which leads to an average Pearson correlation 3 of 0.95 between results of subsets of this size, and results of the full set of sorting data. Nielsen (2004) regards a Pearson correlation of 0.9 as sufficient. Using the data of Tullis and Wood (2004), he recommends a sample size of 15. This section adds to that information. It uses data from six different sorting studies, while previous information was based on data from just one domain of items. The focus is on sample size requirements of CFA. All results of this section pertain to descriptive configuration frequency counting of free sorting data.

sec.title: Sets of Sorting Data Employed
sec.p: Six sets of sorting data are used in this present study. The data sets differ in theme, but also in number of items sorted and number of participants employed. For better compatibility with older studies, only partition sortings are used herein. The first data set comes from the partition sortings of the consultancy Web site item’s study of Harloff (2008) which has been already introduced. Adding a few sortings it now comprises 25 items and 53 sortings. The kinship term data set of Rosenberg (1982) is also used. It is part of Rosenberg and Kim’s results (1975) about family relationship structures. It has 15 items and 85 participants. A third data set of 20 colour plates sorted by 76 participants also comes from Harloff (2008), adding some new sortings. Adrian Stringer and Anthony Coxon (2011) kindly provided a fourth set of sorting data about social identities of 46 Northern Irish church members, sorting 27 different social groups in terms of which went together. Anthony Coxon (2004, 2006) additionally contributed sorting data from 69 participants, who sorted 28 drugs according to perceived similarity. Jennifer Hawkey (2005) kindly provided a sixth set of 50 sortings from British women who had to imagine they were pregnant. The participants had to sort prenatal tests for 30 different conditions according to their similarity.

sec.title: Descriptive Methods
sec.p: As described above, only a tiny fraction of potential configurations is realized in sorting studies. Therefore, we might expect that after some number of sorting experiments, we reach an upper limit of the number of different configurations realized. Further experiments would add nothing further to the present information. This idea was investigated using a bootstrap-like simulation study similar to the method employed by Tullis and Wood (2004). For all sets of sorting data, random subsets of sortings were drawn with set sizes increasing in steps of 5 sortings up to the full sample size. For each set size, 2,000 random subsamples were drawn from the full sample of sortings and each time the number of different configurations encountered was then determined. Figure 2 shows the relationship between the average number of different configurations found and the sample size.

fig.label: Figure 2.

caption.p: Number of configurations identified on average from 2,000 subsamples (y axis) dependent on the number of sortings combined in each of the subsamples (x axis)

fig.p: (The slopes of the curves increase with the number of items present in the domains.)

sec.p: As pointed out above, qualitative interpretation of frequency tables and graph figures will be easier when restricted to configurations occurring more often than a minimum frequency threshold. However, when only few sortings are investigated, the frequency and the frequency rank of a given configuration may be unstable if another sorting is added. The question is how many sortings are needed to reach a stable order of configurations. Similar to the first study, for each of the six sets of sorting data, 2,000 random subsets of all sortings available were drawn for all sample sizes, increasing in steps of 5 from 1 to the full sample size. For each subset, an ordered frequency table of configurations was produced and Kendall’s τ rank correlation coefficient 4 was determined between the frequencies of configurations of this table and the respective configurations in the full samples frequency table. Kendall’s τ was then averaged over the 2,000 subsets related to each sample size. The results are shown in Figure 3 . Kendall’s τ relates to the number of moves of configurations required to transform one frequency table’s order of configurations to the order of the second table. It therefore has a particularly good face validity 5 for the question at hand.

caption.p: Average Kendall’s τ rank correlation between configuration frequencies of 2,000 sub-samples for varying subsample sizes (x axis) and the configuration frequencies obtained from the full sample of all sortings

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Figure 2 shows a simple, approximately logarithmic relationship between the number of sortings (the sample size of the sorting study) and the number of different configurations produced by these sortings. Comparison of the different sets of sorting data shows that the number of configurations increases regularly with the number of items employed. In a double logarithmic plot of log(sample size) by log(number of configurations), each of the curves shown in Figure 2 were straight lines and the lines' gradient was approximately proportional to the number of items.

A mathematical representation for these observations was attempted. Possibly the number of configurations produced from a sorting study could be predicted from the number of sortings employed (the sample size) and the number of items constituting the sorted domain. Therefore, the following linear model was fitted to the data by regression using the lm object of R (R Development Core Team, 2010):
ln(number of different configurations identified) = 2.043 + ln(sample size) * (0.026 + 0.030 * (number of items))

The residual standard error of the model is 0.143. The error levels for the intercept (2.043), the coefficient (0.026 + 0.030 * (number of items)) and the F statistic for equality of variance are all below the computer’s accuracy. Therefore, in general, the fit between the data and the (fitted) model is good. The strongest deviation of the sorting data sets is in the optimal intercept. The colour plate and kinship term data fitted somewhat worse than the other data sets, but still acceptably.

Figure 3 shows no simple relationship between subsample size and Kendall’s τ rank correlation between subsample frequencies and full sample frequencies of the same configurations. The shape and slope of the curves obtained for different domains vary.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Somewhat surprisingly, the different qualities of the domains sorted did not introduce a major error term to the empirical model described. A sample of six different domains is not sufficient to prove the reliability of the model in a statistical sense. Therefore, the model may undergo future testing. From Figure 2, it appears that a finite number of different configurations cannot be reached within a common number of sortings (participants) if a domain includes more than 15 approximately items. However, the number of 15 items is represented by just one domain, which might possibly have behaved exceptionally well. Therefore, more data sets are required to investigate the idea. Judging from Figures 2 and 3, I think that probably some of the full samples used herein are still too small to have reached a stable result. This puts a different light on sample size requirements of the sorting method. From Figure 3, it appears that qualities of the domains strongly influence the rate of convergence of the frequency rank order of configurations. It may therefore be a good strategy to collect some 20 to 30 sortings and subsequently use their results to consider if or how many additional sortings are required for reliable results.

sec.title: An Example of Hypothesis Testing Using CFA
Method
sec.p: Until now, the method of sorting has never been combined with inferential statistics. Therefore, a new suitable method is derived from standard frequency statistics, similar to Krauth and Lienert’s test (1973a, 1973b) for configural frequency analysis. But Krauth and Lienerts test is about configurations (or syndromes) identified in presence/absence data of a fixed set of attributes for a set of specimens. All attributes of each specimen are measured just once. This paradigm is equivalent to closed partition sorting, if each participant built just one group of items. The present modification is applicable to free fuzzy sorting data where participants are free to build as many groups as they like and items can be members of any number of those groups. The test is a permutation test (exact test) based on the assumption that a priori the presence (or absence) of an item in a group is equally likely for all groups of items built; predetermined by the items frequency in the sorting in relation to the number of groups built. Note that the present method relies on the absence of items as much as it does on the presence of items in groups. The method also assumes that any sorting fulfilling the previous conditions is equally likely to occur. It finally sums up the chances for a certain configuration to occur in all the potential sortings. Because of the huge number of permutations involved, an application of the method is restricted to a small number of sortings (some 20 on current computers) and items using the algorithm and Java code presented in the annex.

The proposed method is suited to test the null hypothesis of one single configuration's frequency being less than, equal to, or larger than the frequency expected from the marginal sums. For a few hypotheses tested concurrently, it may be considered to adjust the type I error level accepted (for details, see Lautsch and Von Weber, 1995).

sec.title: Data and Hypothesis Tested
sec.p: An application of the new test is exemplified using a true fuzzy sorting subset of the consultancy Web site data explained above. Figure 1 and Table 1 show the 25 items sorted, which were constructed from actual contents of a consultancy's Web site and overworked to be mutually exclusive. The sorting task consisted of filling in a checkbox paper questionnaire as described in detail by Harloff (2008). Items were written in separate rows of a table printed on paper, and participants marked columns corresponding to groups of items. 22 German business people independently from each other filled in the questionnaire according to which items they expected to occur together on pages of a Web site. The instructions given to participants explicitly allowed for group overlap denoting full presence of items in two or more groups. The participants were allowed to repeatedly erase and redraw everything until the result suited them. The questionnaires were used for storage of the results. Qualitative interviews of the participants (business people) were conducted after each sorting exercise including a series of questions listed in Harloff and Coxon (2005). Among other questions participants were asked if they had any issues with the placement of items and if they believed that any item did not belong to the domain sorted. As a result several participants expressed their reservations about “headquarters as a historical monument” as being part of the company’s Web site. Reading such information would cost them Company time but not improve their regard of the company’s integrity. From the instructions given to participants there was no “out of the domain” category available for sorting but participants isolated dubious items in singleton categories. Configural frequency counting showed that a “headquarters as a historical monument” singleton configuration occurred 9 times in 22 sortings, where the frequency expected from marginal sums was 1. Therefore, a null hypothesis is tested that a frequency of 9 or more of this configuration could have occurred. A type I error of 0.05 is considered acceptable to reject the null hypothesis.

sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: A P(X ≥ m) of 1.3 * 10−17 was obtained for the “headquarters as a historical monument” singleton configuration. Therefore, it is safe to conclude that “headquarters as a historical monument” has been isolated in a singleton configuration significantly more often than expected by chance. This result further supports the evidence obtained from the qualitative interviews. Web designers should therefore consider omitting this item from a Web site.

sec.title: General Discussion
sec.p: CFA is a very simple supplementary tool for qualitative analysis of sorting data which can provide detailed information. Frequency tables can be difficult to interpret, but drawing separate graphs in network figures can be more readily interpreted than uniform network figures. Typically configuration frequencies within sorting data are distributed very unevenly with a few common and many rare and unique configurations. The majority of possible configurations are never realized, which implies that participants are applying highly efficient concepts for classification.

CFA as an inferential statistical tool is new to the field of sorting data. Because the configurations tested stem from different sortings (participants), a requirement is that the groups are sorted by participants who remain formally independent from each other. This is true for fuzzy sorting, but not for partition sorting which up to now prevails in sorting studies. The characteristics of sorting data contingency tables prohibit the use of χ2 testing methods. A new test procedure is proposed. It relates to the binomial test formula of Krauth and Lienert (1973a, 1973b), adapted to varying numbers of clusters per sorting and varying item frequencies per sorting.

With respect to sample size requirements for qualitative interpretations, new results are presented. Based on data from six different domains, an empirical model is proposed estimating the number of different configurations encountered from the number of items present and the number of sortings obtained. This model has still to be confirmed using additional data sets, but it shows that different domains require different sample sizes and therefore improves current assumptions that are based on one data set only. With the data sets available for this study, for domains including more than approximately 15 items, no upper limit of different configurations identified was encountered. It is possible that the kinship data set simply showed an unusually high agreement among participants about relationships in their family. If so, the apparent upper limit of different configurations was not due to a low number of items, but rather to an exceptional characteristic of this particular domain. It is not possible to reach a conclusion on this without additional sets of data. It also appears that sample sizes in the range of 43 to 76 were mostly insufficient to approach a stable rank order of configuration frequencies. Together these observations about numbers of different configurations and their frequency ranks throw a different light on sample size requirements than statements in literature requiring approximately 20-30 sortings. They tend to imply that the stated size is a good starting point to see how fast the results converge and judge if more sortings are possibly required for a reliable, interpretable result.

fn.p: The Dice index (also called Czekanowski index) as a similarity index is si,j = 2a / (2a + b + c), where a is the number of groups including both items i and j, b is the number of groups including only i and c is the number of groups including only j. The Dice index is subtracted from 1 to give distance values di,j = 1 − si,j. The emphasis on a relates better to the instructions given to participants of a sorting study than other R-mode distance measures. At the same time it has a likelihood of co-occurrence interpretation, hence the term “Dice”.

Bootstrapping is a method to evaluate the distribution of some statistic of as yet unknown properties. The statistic is computed for each of numerous subsamples drawn from a large sample. The resulting empirical distribution of the statistic is examined, since the unknown theoretical distribution is not available.

The Pearson correlation r, also known as Pearson's Product-Moment Correlation Coefficient, of two series X, Y of real numbers is defined as r = Covariance(X,Y)/ √(Variance(X) * Variance(Y)). It ranges from −1 to 1 where 1 means perfect correlation and 0 means no correlation (independence) of X and Y. It is a valid measure of linear correlation relationships but its application is less valid if the values of X and Y are not almost normally distributed. Tullis and Wood (2004) summed up distance matrices of items over the full sample of participants (X) and over random subsamples of participants (Y) and calculated the Pearson correlation of the distance matrices X and Y while varying subsample size (bootstrapping).

Validity of a measure is the extent to which the measure indicates the size of the parameter it is supposed to indicate. Good face validity of a measure means that it looks like being well suited for the targeted parameter or property.
